message_1:
A sample of Uranium-238 has an initial mass of 80 grams. The half-life of Uranium-238 is 4.5 billion years. 

a) Determine the amount of Uranium-238 that will remain after 13.5 billion years.

b) How many half-lives have passed after 13.5 billion years? 

c) What was the initial mass of the sample if 20 grams remains after 4.5 billion years?
message_2:
a) To determine the amount of Uranium-238 that will remain after 13.5 billion years, we can use the formula:

Final mass = Initial mass * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

Final mass = 80 grams * (1/2)^(13.5 billion years / 4.5 billion years)

Final mass = 80 grams * (1/2)^3

Final mass = 80 grams * (1/8)

Final mass = 10 grams

So, 10 grams of Uranium-238 will remain after 13.5 billion years.

b) To find out how many half-lives have passed after 13.5 billion years, we can simply divide the time elapsed by the half-life:

Number of half-lives = Time elapsed / Half-life

Number of half-lives = 13.5 billion years / 4.5 billion years

Number of half-lives = 3

So, 3 half-lives have passed after 13.5 billion years.

c) To find the initial mass of the sample if 20 grams remains after 4.5 billion years, we can use the same formula as in part a, but rearrange it to solve for the initial mass:

Initial mass = Final mass / (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

Initial mass = 20 grams / (1/2)^(4.5 billion years / 4.5 billion years)

Initial mass = 20 grams / (1/2)^1

Initial mass = 20 grams / 0.5

Initial mass = 40 grams

So, the initial mass of the sample was 40 grams.
